actionItems.text: Discuss elevated blood pressure (138/88 mmHg) - target is <130/80
actionItems.trigger: Blood pressure averaging 138/88 mmHg, above target of 130/80

actionItems.text: Review elevated resting heart rate (up 9% this week to 68 bpm)
actionItems.trigger: Resting heart rate increased 9% correlating with 15% decline in sleep quality

actionItems.text: Ask about persistent dry cough - possible Lisinopril side effect
actionItems.trigger: Common side effect of Lisinopril (persistent dry cough)

actionItems.text: Discuss Lisinopril dosage adjustment based on BP readings
actionItems.trigger: BP still elevated despite current 20mg dosage

actionItems.text: Report muscle pain or weakness while taking Atorvastatin
actionItems.trigger: Age 58, male - higher risk of muscle-related side effects with statins

actionItems.text: Review kidney function (eGFR >60) - important for Metformin safety
actionItems.trigger: Age 58 - kidney function monitoring recommended for patients over 50 on Metformin

actionItems.text: Discuss Aspirin interaction with Lisinopril (may reduce BP-lowering effect)
actionItems.trigger: Medium severity drug interaction detected between Aspirin and Lisinopril

actionItems.text: Review A1C result of 6.8% - close to target of <7%
actionItems.trigger: A1C at 6.8%, within target range but could be optimized

actionItems.text: Celebrate LDL improvement - down 23% to 112 mg/dL with Atorvastatin
actionItems.trigger: LDL cholesterol decreased from 145 to 112 mg/dL (23% improvement)

actionItems.text: Address poor sleep quality (down 15%) affecting heart rate and stress
actionItems.trigger: Sleep quality decreased 15% with correlated rise in resting heart rate next day
actionItems.source: AI correlation: Sleep decline → HR increase

actionItems.text: Ask about nausea from Metformin - common early side effect
actionItems.trigger: Nausea is common side effect of Metformin (likelihood: common, severity: low)

actionItems.text: Verify blood glucose trends (avg 118 mg/dL, down 5%)
actionItems.trigger: Average blood glucose down 5% - Metformin working well

diagnoses.name: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition where your body doesn't use insulin properly, leading to high blood sugar levels. Managed through diet, exercise, and medication.

latestAssessment.notes: Patient continues to do well on current Metformin regimen. Recent A1C of 6.8% demonstrates excellent glycemic control. Blood glucose averages have improved 5% over the past month per wearable data. Patient reports good medication adherence and has been mindful of carbohydrate intake. No hypoglycemic episodes reported. Will continue current treatment plan.

treatmentPlan: Continue Metformin 1000mg twice daily with meals
Maintain A1C target of <7%
Monitor blood glucose with continuous glucose monitor
Follow Mediterranean diet with controlled carbohydrate portions
Regular exercise 150 minutes per week
Quarterly A1C checks and annual comprehensive metabolic panel

criticalEvents.description: A1C 6.8% - well-controlled, down from 7.1% in September
A1C 7.1% - slightly above target, Metformin dose optimized
Type 2 Diabetes diagnosed with A1C of 8.2%, started on Metformin

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure - when the force of blood against artery walls is consistently too high (typically 140/90 mmHg or higher).

latestAssessment.notes: Blood pressure readings remain elevated despite Lisinopril 20mg. Patient's average BP over the past 2 weeks is 138/88 mmHg, which is above our target of <130/80. Patient reports persistent dry cough which is a known side effect of ACE inhibitors. Wearable data shows correlation between poor sleep quality and elevated morning BP readings. Plan to increase Lisinopril to 30mg and reassess in 3 weeks. If dry cough persists, may need to switch to ARB class medication.

treatmentPlan: Increase Lisinopril from 20mg to 30mg once daily
Target BP <130/80 mmHg
Daily home BP monitoring (morning and evening)
Reduce sodium intake to <2000mg per day
Address sleep quality issues to help with BP control
Follow-up appointment in 3 weeks to reassess medication efficacy
Consider medication class change if dry cough persists

criticalEvents.description: BP 142/90 - elevated despite medication, dosage increase planned
7-day average BP 138/88 mmHg - consistently above target
BP 135/85 - improved but still above goal, continued current dose
Hypertension diagnosed with BP 145/92, started on Lisinopril 10mg

diagnoses.name: Hyperlipidemia
diagnoses.description: High levels of fats (lipids) in the blood, including cholesterol and triglycerides. Can increase risk of heart disease.

latestAssessment.notes: Excellent response to Atorvastatin therapy. LDL cholesterol has decreased from 145 mg/dL to 112 mg/dL (23% reduction), moving closer to our goal of <100 mg/dL for cardiovascular risk reduction. HDL remains stable at 48 mg/dL, and triglycerides are well-controlled at 135 mg/dL. Patient denies muscle pain or weakness. Continue current statin dose and recheck lipid panel in 6 months. Encouraged patient to increase physical activity which may further improve HDL levels.

treatmentPlan: Continue Atorvastatin 40mg once daily at bedtime
Target LDL <100 mg/dL for ASCVD risk reduction
Monitor for muscle pain or weakness (statin side effect)
Increase aerobic exercise to 30+ minutes, 5 days per week
Mediterranean diet with emphasis on healthy fats
Lipid panel every 6 months
Annual liver function tests while on statin therapy

criticalEvents.description: LDL 112 mg/dL - improved 23% from baseline, approaching goal
LDL 128 mg/dL - gradual improvement on Atorvastatin 40mg
Atorvastatin increased from 20mg to 40mg for better LDL control
Hyperlipidemia diagnosed with LDL 165 mg/dL, started on Atorvastatin 20mg

medications.name: Metformin
medications.purpose: Controls blood sugar levels in Type 2 Diabetes

interactions.warning: May increase risk of low blood sugar when combined with blood pressure medications

demographicRisks.note: Kidney function should be monitored regularly in patients over 50

wearableInsights.note: Your average blood glucose is down 5% - medication is working well

conditionWarnings.note: Primary medication for your diabetes - continue as prescribed

medications.name: Lisinopril
medications.purpose: Manages high blood pressure and protects heart

interactions.warning: Aspirin may reduce the blood pressure-lowering effect of Lisinopril
interactions.whatToWatch: Monitor your blood pressure readings regularly

interactions.warning: May enhance blood sugar lowering effects

wearableInsights.note: Your average BP is 138/88, still slightly elevated - may need dosage adjustment
Your resting heart rate is up 9% this week, which may indicate stress affecting BP control

conditionWarnings.note: Current dosage may need adjustment based on recent BP readings

medications.name: Atorvastatin
medications.purpose: Lowers cholesterol to reduce heart disease risk

interactions.warning: Can interact with certain antibiotics and antifungals - inform all doctors you're taking this

demographicRisks.note: Higher risk of muscle-related side effects in older adults - report any muscle pain immediately

wearableInsights.note: LDL down 23% to 112 mg/dL - excellent progress with current dose
Regular activity (127 min/week) helps maximize cholesterol medication effectiveness

conditionWarnings.note: Dosage increased from 20mg to 40mg in September - monitoring shows good response

medications.name: Aspirin
medications.purpose: Prevents blood clots and reduces heart attack risk

interactions.warning: May reduce effectiveness of blood pressure medication
Significantly increases bleeding risk when combined with other blood thinners
interactions.whatToWatch: Unusual bruising, blood in stool or urine, prolonged bleeding from cuts

demographicRisks.note: Increased bleeding risk with age - take with food to reduce stomach irritation

conditionWarnings.note: Prescribed for heart disease prevention given diabetes, hypertension, and cholesterol history

events.title: Cardiology Follow-Up
events.description: Routine follow-up for hypertension management. Blood pressure readings show improvement with current medication regimen.

aiSummary.whatHappened: You had a checkup with your heart doctor to see how your blood pressure medication is working. The good news is that your blood pressure has improved since starting Lisinopril.
aiSummary.whyItMatters: Regular follow-ups help make sure your blood pressure stays in a healthy range, which protects your heart and blood vessels from damage over time. High blood pressure can lead to heart attacks and strokes if left unmanaged.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: High blood pressure - when the force of blood pushing against your artery walls is too strong
The branch of medicine focused on heart and blood vessel health

keyNumbers.context: This is down from 138/88 last month. Your target is below 130/80, so you're getting close!

actionsTaken: Blood pressure measured and reviewed
Current medication dosage confirmed as working well
Discussed lifestyle changes (diet, exercise) to support treatment
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Continue current Lisinopril 20mg daily. Next cardiology visit scheduled in 3 months to recheck progress.

events.title: Comprehensive Metabolic Panel
events.description: Regular monitoring of blood glucose, kidney function, and overall metabolic health status.

jargonTerms.definition: A group of blood tests that measure various substances in your blood, including glucose, electrolytes, and kidney function markers.

aiSummary.whatHappened: You had blood work done to check your blood sugar control, kidney function, and overall body chemistry. All your results came back in the healthy range!
aiSummary.whyItMatters: These tests help track how well your diabetes medication is working and make sure your kidneys are staying healthy. Since Metformin (your diabetes medicine) is processed by the kidneys, it's important to check that they're functioning properly.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: A test that shows your average blood sugar level over the past 2-3 months. Think of it as your 'report card' for diabetes management.
Estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate - a measure of how well your kidneys are filtering waste from your blood. Higher is better.
A waste product that healthy kidneys filter out. Normal levels mean your kidneys are working well.
Blood sugar level at the time of the test (a snapshot, not an average)

keyNumbers.context: Your target is below 7%, so you're doing great! This means your average blood sugar over the past 3 months has been well-controlled.
Normal range is 70-130 mg/dL for people with diabetes. You're right in the middle - perfect!
This shows your kidneys are filtering properly. Above 60 is considered normal kidney function.
Normal range is 0.7-1.3, so your kidneys are clearing waste effectively.

actionsTaken: Blood drawn and sent to lab for analysis
Results reviewed by Dr. Chen
Confirmed Metformin is safe to continue based on kidney function
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Continue current medications. Repeat metabolic panel in 3-6 months to keep monitoring kidney function and blood sugar control.

events.title: Emergency Room Visit
events.description: Presented with chest pain and shortness of breath. Cardiac workup negative for acute coronary syndrome. Diagnosed with anxiety-related symptoms.

jargonTerm.definition: A protein released when heart muscle is damaged. Used to diagnose heart attacks.

events.outcome: No cardiac event detected. Recommended stress management and follow-up with primary care.

aiSummary.whatHappened: You went to the ER with chest pain and difficulty breathing. The doctors ran several heart tests, and the good news is that your heart was fine - no heart attack or heart damage. The symptoms were determined to be anxiety-related.
aiSummary.whyItMatters: Chest pain is always taken seriously because it can be a sign of a heart attack. The doctors did the right tests to rule this out completely. Now you know your heart is healthy, but anxiety can cause very real physical symptoms that feel scary.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: A group of conditions caused by reduced blood flow to the heart, including heart attacks. The tests showed you didn't have this.
A test that records the electrical activity of your heart. Like a 'rhythm check' for your heartbeat.
A protein that leaks into your blood when heart muscle is damaged. Your level was negative, meaning no heart damage occurred.
Normal heartbeat pattern. This is what you want to see on an EKG.

keyNumbers.context: If you were having a heart attack, this number would be elevated. Negative is excellent - no heart damage.
Your heart's electrical system is working perfectly with a regular, healthy rhythm.

actionsTaken: Transported to ER via ambulance for evaluation
EKG performed to check heart rhythm
Blood test (troponin) to rule out heart attack
Full cardiac workup completed - all negative
Diagnosed with anxiety-related chest pain
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Follow up with your primary care doctor to discuss anxiety management strategies. Consider stress reduction techniques like deep breathing, meditation, or counseling if symptoms continue.

events.title: Medication Adjustment
events.description: Atorvastatin dosage increased from 20mg to 40mg to better manage cholesterol levels.

aiSummary.whatHappened: Your cholesterol medication (Atorvastatin) was increased from 20mg to 40mg because your LDL cholesterol (the 'bad' cholesterol) was still a bit too high on the lower dose.
aiSummary.whyItMatters: LDL cholesterol can build up in your arteries like plaque, making them narrower and increasing your risk of heart attacks and strokes. The goal is to get your LDL below 100 mg/dL to protect your heart long-term.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: A statin medication that lowers cholesterol by blocking an enzyme your liver uses to make cholesterol
Low-Density Lipoprotein - the 'bad' cholesterol that can clog arteries. Lower numbers are better.
Changing the amount of medication you take to get better results

keyNumbers.context: Your LDL was above the target of 100 mg/dL, so the dose needed to be increased.
Down 23% from 145! The higher dose is working much better. You're getting closer to the goal.

actionsTaken: Cholesterol levels reviewed from recent lab work
Decision made to increase Atorvastatin from 20mg to 40mg daily
New prescription sent to pharmacy
Follow-up lab scheduled in 3 months to check effectiveness
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Continue Atorvastatin 40mg once daily at bedtime. Repeat cholesterol panel in 3 months to assess whether LDL has reached target of <100 mg/dL.

events.title: Annual Physical Examination
events.description: Comprehensive annual physical. All vitals within normal range. Diabetes and hypertension management discussed.

aiSummary.whatHappened: You had your yearly checkup where Dr. Thompson reviewed your overall health, checked all your vitals, and discussed how your diabetes and blood pressure are being managed.
aiSummary.whyItMatters: Annual physicals are like a 'full system check' for your body. They catch problems early when they're easier to treat and make sure your current medications are still working well for you.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: Basic body measurements like blood pressure, heart rate, temperature, and weight that show how your body is functioning
A number calculated from your height and weight that helps assess if you're at a healthy weight

keyNumbers.context: Your weight has been stable, which is good - no sudden changes that might indicate a problem.
This is in the 'elevated' range. Target is below 130/80. This led to the decision to refer you to a cardiologist.
This falls in the 'overweight' range (25-29.9). Losing 10-15 lbs could help with both diabetes and blood pressure.

actionsTaken: Complete physical examination performed
All vitals measured and recorded
Reviewed current diabetes and hypertension medications
Discussed lifestyle modifications (diet, exercise)
Decided to refer to cardiology due to elevated BP
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Cardiology referral for blood pressure management. Continue current medications. Work on modest weight loss through diet and exercise.

events.title: Cardiology Referral
events.description: Referred to cardiology for elevated blood pressure and family history of cardiovascular disease.

aiSummary.whatHappened: Your primary care doctor referred you to a heart specialist (cardiologist) because your blood pressure has been consistently high and you have a family history of heart disease.
aiSummary.whyItMatters: Specialists have extra training in specific areas. A cardiologist can fine-tune your blood pressure treatment and make sure your heart and blood vessels are protected, especially since heart disease runs in your family.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: When your regular doctor sends you to a heart specialist for more focused care
Conditions affecting the heart and blood vessels, including heart attacks, strokes, and high blood pressure
Health conditions that run in your family - these can increase your own risk of developing the same issues

actionsTaken: Referral created to cardiology department
Patient's medical records sent to cardiologist
Appointment scheduled with Dr. Emily Chen
Blood pressure trends and family history documented
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Attend cardiology appointment with Dr. Chen to develop specialized treatment plan for hypertension management.

events.title: Initial Diabetes Diagnosis
events.description: Type 2 Diabetes diagnosed following elevated fasting glucose and A1C test. Treatment plan initiated.

aiSummary.whatHappened: This was the day you were diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes. Your blood sugar tests (fasting glucose and A1C) both came back high, confirming the diagnosis. Your doctor started you on a treatment plan right away.
aiSummary.whyItMatters: Getting diagnosed with diabetes is a major health milestone, but the good news is that Type 2 Diabetes can be managed very effectively with medication, diet, and lifestyle changes. Early detection and treatment prevent serious complications like heart disease, kidney damage, and vision problems.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: A condition where your body doesn't use insulin properly, causing blood sugar to stay too high. Unlike Type 1, your body still makes insulin.
Your blood sugar level after not eating for 8+ hours. Above 126 mg/dL indicates diabetes.
A test showing your average blood sugar over 2-3 months. Above 6.5% indicates diabetes.

keyNumbers.context: Normal is under 100 mg/dL, prediabetes is 100-125, and diabetes is 126+. You were clearly in the diabetes range.
Normal is below 5.7%, prediabetes is 5.7-6.4%, diabetes is 6.5+. Your 8.2% confirmed the diagnosis.
You've improved from 8.2% to 6.8% - that's excellent progress! Shows your treatment plan is working.

actionsTaken: Diabetes diagnosis confirmed with lab results
Started Metformin 500mg twice daily
Referred to diabetes educator for training
Given glucose meter for home monitoring
Discussed diet modifications and exercise plan
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Follow-up in 3 months to check A1C response to Metformin. Continue daily blood sugar monitoring and lifestyle changes.

events.title: First Recorded Visit
events.description: Initial comprehensive health assessment. All baseline measurements recorded for future comparison.

aiSummary.whatHappened: This was your very first visit where the doctor did a complete health assessment and recorded all your 'baseline' measurements - think of it as taking a starting snapshot of your health.
aiSummary.whyItMatters: Baseline measurements are super important because they give doctors something to compare against in the future. When they see changes over time, they can spot problems early and track whether treatments are working.

medicalTermsExplained.simple: The first set of measurements that become your 'starting point' for tracking health changes over time
A thorough check of your overall health including vitals, blood work, medical history, and physical exam

keyNumbers.context: Your starting weight in 2019. You're now at 178 lbs - down 7 pounds!
This was elevated even at your first visit, which is why BP has been monitored closely since then.
This was in the prediabetes range (100-125), which predicted your diabetes diagnosis 10 months later.

actionsTaken: Complete medical history taken
Physical examination performed
All baseline vitals recorded (BP, weight, height, heart rate)
Initial blood work ordered
Established relationship with primary care provider
aiSummary.followUpNeeded: Return for annual physical exam. Monitor blood pressure and blood sugar levels given elevated baseline readings.

aiInsight.description: Your sleep quality decreased by 15% this week. This correlates with increased stress markers and elevated resting heart rate (+9%) the following days.

hrv.interpretation: Slightly below normal - may indicate stress or fatigue
